items.title: How to set my metric path when creating a custom collector?
items.body:
Hi

I'm trying to create my own collector, but I'm having problems with the path. The collector is called "MyCustomCollector" and the code is as simple as:
```
import diamond.collector

class MyCustomCollector(diamond.collector.Collector):
    def collect(self):
        metric_name = "my_test"
        metric_value = 42
        self.publish(metric_name, metric_value)
```
I expected to find the metric at servers.hostname.my_test, but it's being written to servers.hostname.MyCustomCollector.my_test. There's nothing about setting the metric path on the ExampleCollector documentation, so I'm not sure how to change that.

Any hint?

Thanks!

items.title: MongoDB collector reports partial metrics
items.body:
MongoDB metrics are taken from `db.serverStatus` and lots of metric names contain white spaces.
Therefore they are not published on Graphite.
For instance: `wiredTiger.cache.eviction server evicting pages` and so on.
A PR is following.
Regards
ben

items.title: Add support to jbossapi to fetch thread pool statistics
items.body:
If you use a named thread pool in jboss you are able to collect the thread pools statistics using the threads subsystem from the management API.

For example:

```
/management/subsystem/threads?include-runtime=true&recursive=true
```

You end up getting something like this back:

```

  "blocking-queueless-thread-pool": null,
  "queueless-thread-pool": null,
  "scheduled-thread-pool": null,
  "thread-factory": null,
  "unbounded-queue-thread-pool": null,
  "bounded-queue-thread-pool": {
    "ajp-executor": {
      "allow-core-timeout": false,
      "core-threads": null,
      "current-thread-count": 26,
```

items.title: kafka per topic metrics (kafka >= 0.9)
items.body:
hello,

the kafkastat collector for some reason supports only splitting 2 optional "=" in each mx4j metric at most.
this prevents getting the topic metrics (per each topic).

the fix is very small:

instead of:  

``` python
elif i > 0:
    key = objectname.split('=')[2]
```

should be something like:  

``` python
elif i > 0:
    key = objectname.split('=')[i+1]
```

this would be very helpful !

items.title: Diskspace Collector incorrectly calculating bytes on OSX Yosemite
items.body:
Hey,

I've been evaluating Diamond on my local OSX machine and noticed that the DiskSpace collector was giving me bogus results (saying I had ~3000 GB free on my 250 GB hard drive). Strangely, however, I noticed that the "percentfree" metric looked pretty much spot on. After digging into the code it looks like the problem was where we [set block_size to f_bsize](https://github.com/python-diamond/Diamond/blob/master/src/collectors/diskspace/diskspace.py#L215), after consulting a [few other resources](http://stackoverflow.com/questions/4260116/find-size-and-free-space-of-the-filesystem-containing-a-given-file) I replaced block_size with f_frsize and was getting the proper calculations.

It looks like on some systems (tested on Ubuntu at least) f_bsize and f_frsize are the same but on my Yosemite machine f_bsize was "1048576" while f_frsize was the much more reasonable "4096". I decided to open up a ticket rather than submit a pull request because to be perfectly honest I don't know too much about the differences between f_bsize and f_frsize and don't know what all ramifications of the change might be, however I will be making the change on my own fork.

items.title: NetworkCollector and device names
items.body:
Hi team.

Can you please make changes to NetworkCollector?
It can take the interface names directly from a file /proc/net/dev.
I do not want every time to make a large number of interface names in the configuration file, and restart diamond, if the interface names are called as well as the name of the VPS. 
This can be controlled in the configuration file. 
For example, if the list of interfaces empty in the config - taken from the file /proc/net/dev, else from a list in config file.
It will also help to automate more user-friendly.

Regards,
Alex

items.title: In HBase and Hadoop collectors, filename globbing doesn't work when only one pattern is specified
items.body: In the HBase and Hadoop collectors, if only one globbing pattern for metrics filenames is provided, the loop in `collect()` treats the list of patterns as a single string and attempts to iterate over the string's characters. This results in the collector trying to glob over individual characters instead of the string as a whole, breaking the collectors.

items.title: Unable to Disable DEBUG Log on Diamond
items.body:
The only way I've found to actually disable (verbose) logging, diamond.conf

[server]
change this 
handlers = diamond.handler.graphite.GraphiteHandler, diamond.handler.archive.ArchiveHandler
to that
handlers = diamond.handler.graphite.GraphiteHandler

A possible way to logging is: log WARN+ERROR for system level diamond process things "WARNING: could not load extra python module libsomething", and ERROR for metrics "ERROR: could not connect to mysql to gather metrics".  but _not_ to log every single metric gathered... that's just way too verbose and not useful, except during debugging

items.title: diamond multiprocessing inherit signal handler
items.body:
if we have collertor, that will be removed later and make diamond reload(send sigHUP), diamond will remove it pid file

Situation is identical like described here:

https://vimmaniac.com/blog/codejunkie/safe-use-of-unix-signals-with-multiprocessing-module-in-python/

In exception that we must set 

```
signal.signal(signal.SIGINT, signal.SIG_DFL)
signal.signal(signal.SIGTERM, signal.SIG_DFL)
```

items.title: Precision
items.body:
I've just started using python-diamond.  I've noticed that some of the collectors work poorly because the precision published is defaulted to 0.

ping:
In order for sub-millisecond ping times to not round to zero I tried setting the precision to 4 in PingCollector.  This was mzupan fixed this in https://github.com/python-diamond/Diamond/pull/109.

postfix:
For low load mail servers, the derivative values in PostfixCollector are better represented with a few digits of precision.  I tried setting it to 3.

lmsensors:
Voltages found in CPUs are generally around a few volts.  As such there is no variation if it is set to a precision of 2.  It would be more useful to report at least a few digits of precision on these values.  I've tried setting precision to 2 in LMSensorsCollector.

ntpd:
Many of the values are reported as zero with the current implementation of NtpdCollector.  I think the precision should either be fixed a lot higher, or vary based on the data type being published.  I set delay and jitter to 6, and offset, frequency, max_error, est_error, root_distance, and root_dispersion to 10, and left the rest at 0.

items.title: unbounded metric_queue can lead to memory exhaustion
items.body:
I was tracking down a memory usage issue with the `SyncManager` process tonight.
After a good look at the code, it seems like under the right circumstances  `SyncManager` can eat up all available memory.

The root of the issue is that the `metric_queue`, that is shared by all collectors, is unbounded.
If, for whatever reason,  the handlers are not popping stuff fast enough from that queue, the `SyncManager` process (which owns the queue) will grow until it reaches the system limit (or gets killed by the OOM killer)

We've encountered this issue with a single graphite handler that was configured with a wrong host,  the host was unreachable and every connection attempt would timeout  (and the default graphite timeout is 15 seconds, that doesn't help either).
We had ~10 collectors running and configured to poll every 10s. After a few hours, the `SyncManager` was _huge_  ;-)

I'm wondering what would be the right approach to fix this, or even if one approach could fit all needs.

In my case, I'd rather lose some metrics than have a process eat up all available memory (before it gets killed... we'd lose the stats anyways).

For this we could add a  (configurable?) maximum queue size:

```
--- a/src/diamond/server.py
+++ b/src/diamond/server.py
@@ -58,7 +58,7 @@ class Server(object):
         self.manager = multiprocessing.Manager()
         if setproctitle:
             setproctitle(oldproctitle)
-        self.metric_queue = self.manager.Queue()
+        self.metric_queue = self.manager.Queue(512)

     def run(self):
         """
```

This would allow for transient handler failure and would limit the memory usage for that queue.

Then, what should be done in the `QueueHandler._flush()` method?  should it drop the current metric and log an error on `Queue.Full` exceptions?  Or should it block until there's some room available?

If it blocks, it would stop consuming resources until the handler recovers,  but then I think there's a `SIGALARM` shotgun that will kick in after a few seconds...

Any opinions on all this?

items.title: ElbCollector causes StatsdHandler to fail
items.body:
When using the ElbCollector in conjunction with the StatsdHandler a failure occurs that causes StatsdHandler to stop emitting metrics for all collectors. This message is logged:

> [2015-09-23 15:00:57,384] [MainThread] Traceback (most recent call last):
>  File "/usr/local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/diamond/handler/Handler.py", line 98, in _flush
>    self.flush()
>  File "/usr/local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/diamond/handler/stats_d.py", line 142, in flush
>    self._send()
>  File "/usr/local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/diamond/handler/stats_d.py", line 129, in _send
>    value = value - self.old_values[metric.path]
> TypeError: unsupported operand type(s) for -: 'NoneType' and 'NoneType'

Upon inspection of stats_d.py, it attempts to calculate a delta for non-gauge values so that it can send a counter (lines 125-136). The relative code is lines 127-130:

``` python
value = metric.raw_value
if metric.path in self.old_values:
    value = value - self.old_values[metric.path]
self.old_values[metric.path] = metric.raw_value
```

The TypeError we see in the log is related to the - operand on types None and None (line 129).

We know, based on this error, that metric.raw_value is NoneType, so I tracked down where that originates from within ElbCollector. Here is the method signature for publish_delayed_metric() (lines 183-206):

``` python
def publish_delayed_metric(self, name, value, timestamp, raw_value=None,
                           precision=0, metric_type='GAUGE',
                           instance=None):
```

None of the places where publish_delayed_metric is called in elb.py set raw_value to anything explicitly, so it is always going to be NoneType. This would not be a problem but some of the metrics sent by ElbCollector are of type COUNTER.

I would like to fix this and enter a pull request, but wanted some guidance as to the coding standards of the project. What is the difference between raw_value and value? If we have ElbCollector always set raw_value equal to value, would this fix the problem?

Thanks.

items.title: upgrade InfluxDB handler to support 0.9x - Request for comment
items.body:
Hi,

InfluxDB reached 0.9.x release with a massive API and organization change. 
It's time to re-write the handler.

Previously, influx was storing metrics like graphite, describing the content using chunks. ex :  servers.myhost.cpu.user.time = 0.2

When searching, a regexp was used to split every parts. This wasn't really effective in influxdb.

InfluxDB 0.9 is using tags to give informations on the metrics. The same example as above could be change to :  
cpu_time: value=0.2 host=myhost type=user

To be able to do that using Diamond, each collector must create its own tags. This could be a massive rewrite !

The name also have to be changed to something that describe the same kind of metric.
Still using the example above, for CPU, I could have many CPUs in the system. The collector will have to tag every metric with the number (or the name) of the CPU, in the same serie name for each metric :

cpu_time: value=0.2 host=myhost type=user cpu=0
cpu_time: value=0.5 host=myhost type=user cpu=1
cpu_time: value=0.2 host=myhost type=nice cpu=0
cpu_time: value=0.5 host=myhost type=nice cpu=1
...

This way, we can easily search for the whole cpu_time (select value from cpu_time), for one specific server (select value from cpu_time where host=myhost) or from one type of cpu usage (select value from cpu_time where host=myhost and type=nice)

This is a big change.

I would like to have your thoughts on this, and maybe a new/better idea to solve this issue and enable the use of influxdb 0.9 with Diamond.

items.title: Diamond does not set groups properly when changing uid and gid
items.body:
According to [Python issue 10032](http://bugs.python.org/issue10032), setting the `uid` and `gid` is not enough to simulate logging in as that user. The `os.initgroups()` function needs to be used to initialize the groups of the user being changed to, like this:

``` python
    if gid != -1 and uid != -1:
        os.initgroups(pwd.getpwuid(uid).pw_name, gid)
```

If this is not done, Diamond can't invoke actions on files when it changes to a user that only has group permissions for those files, since Python doesn't know that it's a member of those groups.

items.title: Postgres password required in diamond config file
items.body:
The postgres collector has a `postgres` default string for the password connection. This basically forces to override the password by writing it in clear text in the `diamond.conf` file or to use a weak auth mode such as  `trust` in `pg_hba.conf`.

There should be a way to not pass a password to the psycopg2 `connect()` function so that the password can be specified in the `.pgpass` file.

items.title: Disk space collector doesn't work on devices with large st_dev
items.body:
os.major is casted as an int, so if your device has a magic number above the unsigned maximum, you get this lovely error:

```
Aug 31 00:41:49 web python: 1440978109.82   [DiskSpaceCollector:32617:ERROR]    Collector failed!
Aug 31 00:41:49 web python: 1440978109.82   [DiskSpaceCollector:32617:ERROR]    /usr/lib/python2.7/site-packages/diamond/utils/scheduler.py:99
Aug 31 00:41:49 web python: Traceback (most recent call last):
Aug 31 00:41:49 web python: File "/usr/lib/python2.7/site-packages/diamond/utils/scheduler.py", line 73, in collector_process
Aug 31 00:41:49 web python: collector._run()
Aug 31 00:41:49 web python: File "/usr/lib/python2.7/site-packages/diamond/collector.py", line 472, in _run
Aug 31 00:41:49 web python: self.collect()
Aug 31 00:41:49 web python: File "/usr/share/diamond/collectors/diskspace/diskspace.py", line 189, in collect
Aug 31 00:41:49 web python: results = self.get_file_systems()
Aug 31 00:41:49 web python: File "/usr/share/diamond/collectors/diskspace/diskspace.py", line 151, in get_file_systems
Aug 31 00:41:49 web python: major = os.major(stat.st_dev)
Aug 31 00:41:49 web python: OverflowError: signed integer is greater than maximum
```

The problem lies here:

```
# Working host, os.major is casted as an init
python -c "import os; stat = os.stat('/'); print type(os.major(stat.st_dev))"
<type 'int'>
# Not working host, value of st_dev is too high
python -c "import os; print os.stat('/');"
posix.stat_result(st_mode=16749, st_ino=2, st_dev=2592126593L, st_nlink=20, st_uid=0, st_gid=0, st_size=4096, st_atime=1440957760, st_mtime=1440957756, st_ctime=1440957756)
```

This is on python 2.7.5, default version on CentOS 7. It's patched in 2.7.9.

We can catch the error with OverflowError: but I think it might be best to rethink how we get the devices numbers..

items.title: Hadoop collector, open read-only if not truncating
items.body: Currently the hadoop collector always opens hadoop metrics files with `'r+'` ... if the settings have `truncate = False` the file should be open `'r'` only to avoid permissions issues under certain circumstances. There is no reason to make the files writeable to the diamond user if not necessary.

items.title: Log file permissions are world-writable
items.body:
Running Diamond on Debian Wheezy built with the included scripts, log files in /var/log/diamond end up with permissions that are too permissive. Example, after a few days of log rotation:

```
$ ls -l /var/log/diamond
total 19752
-rw-rw-rw- 1 root root 2207020 Aug  4 18:52 archive.log
-rw-rw-rw- 1 root root  388605 Jul 28 23:59 archive.log.2015-07-28
-rw-rw-rw- 1 root root 2810123 Jul 29 23:59 archive.log.2015-07-29
-rw-rw-rw- 1 root root 2835343 Jul 30 23:59 archive.log.2015-07-30
-rw-rw-rw- 1 root root 3008676 Jul 31 23:59 archive.log.2015-07-31
-rw-rw-rw- 1 root root 2809072 Aug  1 23:59 archive.log.2015-08-01
-rw-rw-rw- 1 root root 2809079 Aug  2 23:59 archive.log.2015-08-02
-rw-rw-rw- 1 root root 2809082 Aug  3 23:59 archive.log.2015-08-03
-rw-rw-rw- 1 root root    1969 Aug  4 18:05 diamond.log
-rw-rw-rw- 1 root root      59 Jul 29 21:44 diamond.log.2015-07-28
-rw-rw-rw- 1 root root      59 Aug  4 17:27 diamond.log.2015-07-29
-rw-rw-rw- 1 root root   92919 Jul 30 23:59 diamond.log.2015-07-30
-rw-rw-rw- 1 root root   92919 Jul 31 23:59 diamond.log.2015-07-31
-rw-rw-rw- 1 root root   92751 Aug  1 23:59 diamond.log.2015-08-01
-rw-rw-rw- 1 root root   92751 Aug  2 23:58 diamond.log.2015-08-02
-rw-rw-rw- 1 root root   92751 Aug  3 23:58 diamond.log.2015-08-03
```

As you can see, these files are world-writable. The logging handler being used does not have any options for setting permissions, so it seems the umask set for diamond itself is effective here.

See this line: https://github.com/python-diamond/Diamond/blob/master/bin/diamond#L239

Changing this to umask(0o022) fixes the problem, and doesn't seem to cause any other problems, at first glance.

I'm not entirely sure if this is a bug or the intended behavior, but I have noticed that the example config file for diamond shows that the run user can be configured: https://github.com/python-diamond/Diamond/blob/master/conf/diamond.conf.example#L12-L14. However, locally I have noticed that the service in /etc/init.d sources /etc/default/diamond, which has the diamond user hardcoded. Is diamond expected to always run as the system 'diamond' user? Just looking for some clarity here.

Thanks!

items.body:

```
import sys

from diamond.handler.Handler import Handler
from configobj import Section

try:

class cloudwatchHandler(Handler):
```

```
# Directory to load handler configs from
handlers_config_path = /etc/diamond/handlers/
```

The config in diamond.conf is as such:

```
handlers = diamond.handler.mycustomhandler.cloudwatchHandler
```

Is there anything I am missing here? Can someone make a guide on how to add your custom Handlers?

items.title: Mismatch between docs and behavior of PingCollector
items.body:
Suppose `PingCollector` is configured with

```
target_website = 'www.example.org'
```

The documentation ("We extract out the key after target_ and use it in the graphite node we push.") suggests that the metric sent will be `servers.hostname.ping.website`, but the actual metric sent is `servers.hostname.ping.www_example_org`. I don't know what the intended behavior is (and thus whether the doc or the code is wrong), only that there is a mismatch.

items.title: memory_docker.py doesn't log errors connecting to docker
items.body:
I get no errors, even with debug logging, when using the `MemoryDockerCollector`.

However, I figured out that it was having trouble connecting to docker due to a version mis-match:

```
[root@linux-centos6 diamond]# python -c 'import docker; print docker.Client().containers(all=True)'
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<string>", line 1, in <module>
  File "/usr/lib/python2.6/site-packages/docker/client.py", line 440, in containers
    res = self._result(self._get(u, params=params), True)
  File "/usr/lib/python2.6/site-packages/docker/client.py", line 126, in _result
    self._raise_for_status(response)
  File "/usr/lib/python2.6/site-packages/docker/client.py", line 122, in _raise_for_status
    raise errors.APIError(e, response, explanation=explanation)
docker.errors.APIError: 404 Client Error: Not Found ("client and server don't have same version (client : 1.18, server: 1.17)")
```

If that error had shown up as a WARN or ERROR (or even INFO) it would have saved me some time.

BTW: The dependency is actually 'docker-py' not 'docker' at https://github.com/BrightcoveOS/Diamond/blob/master/src/collectors/memory_docker/memory_docker.py#L8

items.title: InfluxdbHandler raise InfluxDBClientError: 404: 404 page not found
items.body:
I found this import is the reason:

```
try:
    from influxdb.client import InfluxDBClient
except ImportError:
    InfluxDBClient = None
```

In fact, when influxdb -v == 0.8.x, the correct import should be:

```
from influxdb.influxdb08 import InfluxDBClient
```

ref: https://github.com/influxdb/influxdb-python/issues/135

items.title: PortStat - Counter not available in 2.6
items.body:
`from collections import Counter` from [here](https://github.com/python-diamond/Diamond/blob/master/src/collectors/portstat/portstat.py#L10) does not work in python 2.6 as it was implemented in 2.7

A backported version of Counter can be located [here](http://code.activestate.com/recipes/576611-counter-class/).  It might be good to include this somewhere in the project as a fallback in case the collections.Counter can't be loaded.

items.title: memory collectors uses wrong property to get actual memory available
items.body:
According to documentation (http://pythonhosted.org/psutil/#psutil.virtual_memory) _free_ isn't the right property to read amount of available memory - https://github.com/python-diamond/Diamond/blob/master/src/collectors/memory/memory.py#L115

```
free: memory not being used at all (zeroed) that is readily available; note that this doesn’t reflect the actual memory available (use ‘available’ instead).
```

items.title: Diamond hemorrhages memory when Graphite server is inaccessible
items.body: I recently ran into a situation on one of my hosts where Diamond 4.0 series was consuming over 3 GB of memory after being unable to connect to Graphite for a couple of hours -- RES in htop appears to grow by 2-3 MB per minute. I'm not sure if this is an issue with unbounded write buffer growth or leaked objects in connection handling, but it presents a serious threat to system stability.
